title: Opposition MPs plot to ‘force second referendum vote next week’
text:
A statue of a lion stands over the River Thames from the Houses of Parliament (Picture: Getty)

Rebel MPs plan to take control of parliament next week and force a second referendum vote, it’s claimed.

Opposition MPs will reportedly seize control of the timetable in the House of Commons from Boris Johnson.

The Prime Minister wants MPs to agree to a General Election on December 12 in exchange for more time discussing the Brexit withdrawal agreement.

But supporters of a second vote are plotting to use a standing order 24 to wrestle control from Mr Johnson.

These standing orders allow an MP to apply to the Speaker John Bercow for an emergency debate during sitting time.

Boris Johnson talks to children as he visits Middleton Primary School In Milton Keynes on Friday (Picture: Reuters)

Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn appeared on ITV to discuss potential general election (Picture: Rex)

If granted, the MP has three minutes to explain why the debate should take place and if approved they normally happen the next day of parliament.

The Guardian reports that the rebel group of MPs would then attempt to introduce either Johnson’s Brexit deal or Theresa May’s withdrawal agreement, with possible votes on adding a customs union and second referendum.

The Brexit process has reached another deadlock with the PM urging Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn to ‘man up’ and agree to an election.

Mr Johnson insisted Britain could still leave the EU on October 31.

He said: ‘We’re in a situation now in which under the terms of the surrender Act which was passed by Parliament, it is up to the EU to decide whether or not we stay in the EU.”

The PM needs votes from Labour MPs to get the two-thirds majority needed in the House of Commons to stage a general election.

But Labour has said it will only back the plan if Mr Johnson makes it ‘absolutely clear’ no deal is off the table and a January extension is granted by the European Union.

Mr Corbyn told ITV: ‘I’ve said all along – take no deal off the table, and we’ll have the election.’

description: Rebel MPs plan to force through an emergency debate over Brexit in the House of Commons.
